title: NASA Opens Space Station to Tourists and Businesses to Promote Commercial Activities
summary: Private trips come as part of a broader effort to jump-start commercial initiatives on the international space station. The U.S. government has formally laid out the welcome mat for space tourists, as part of a broader effort to jump-start commercial initiatives on the international space station.

title: A Jobs Warning for Trump
summary: Weak hiring in May joins other signs of slowing economic growth.. President Trump understandably talks up the job creation on his watch, so he should heed Friday's Labor report that showed a sharp pullback in hiring. The labor-market warning reinforces other evidence that the uncertainty caused by scattershot tariffs is now hurting employment as well as investment.

title: Trump's Tariffs on Mexico Could Slow Trade to a Crawl
summary: Businesses warn about effect on busy commercial corridor if U.S. imposes levies on Monday. The U.S. and Mexico were headed for a weekend of high-stakes negotiations to strike a deal on border security and migration, as truckers, manufacturers and customs brokers warned that the U.S. imposing new tariffs would create major bottlenecks on Monday at one of the world's busiest commercial corridors.

title: Two Top Uber Executives Out Amid Shakeup
summary: Uber Chief Executive Dara Khosrowshahi says, 'This will allow me to be more hands on'. Uber Technologies Inc. Chief Executive Dara Khosrowshahi is taking direct oversight of the ride-sharing company's operations in a management shakeout that comes less than a month after a disappointing initial public offering.

title: Democratic Contenders Rake In Cash From Tech Antitrust Targets
summary: Several presidential hopefuls have harvested big campaign donations from employees of the technology companies they want to break up. No other candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination has been as eager to call for the breakup of Google as Sen. Elizabeth Warren.

title: U.S. and Russia Accuse Each Other After Harrowing Encounter at Sea
summary: Navy says a Russian destroyer came within 100 feet of an American-guided missile cruiser. The U.S. Navy accused Russia's military of unsafe and unprofessional operation at seaafter a Russian destroyer came within 100 feet of an American-guided missile cruiser in the Philippine Sea.

title: Cboe Seeks to Add 'Speed Bump' to Stock Exchange
summary: Proposed delay could undermine fast traders that zip orders via microwave from Illinois to New Jersey. Cboe Global Markets Inc. is proposing to hit the brakes on high-frequency trading by introducing a split-second delay to one of its stock exchanges, according to a new regulatory filing.

title: Kraft Heinz Concludes Internal Investigation Into Accounting Errors
summary: Food conglomerate had delayed financial disclosures after writing down the value of some brands. Kraft Heinz Co. said it had concluded an internal investigation into accounting errors and changed financial practices that triggered a regulatory probe and steep decline in the food maker's stock price.

title: Biden Flips Over Abortion Funding
summary: By the end of the primaries, what will be left of his moderation?. Joe Biden's best claim to the Democratic presidential nomination is that he's a moderate liberal who can pull centrist votes from Donald Trump. That reputation is vanishing by the week as he throws old positions over the side to accommodate his party's activist left.

title: State AGs' Climate Cover-up
summary: What's behind third-party funding of liberal state attorneys general?. Voters are spurning alarmist climate agendas at the ballot box, so U.S. progressives have turned to state attorneys general to litigate against fossil fuels. But the plan is backfiring as an ethically dubious program involving private-interest funding of state AG staff is being confronted in court.

title: Bullying George Washington
summary: A liberal outfit trashes a university for employing skeptics of regulation.. Progressives dominate life in the academy, and they want to keep it that way. That's clear from this week's smear campaign against George Washington University's Regulatory Studies Center.

title: Oil Extends Gains as Oversupply Fears Ease
summary: Record U.S. supply and rising inventories have dented prices lately. Oil prices rallied for the second consecutive session Friday, rebounding after entering a bear market earlier in the week as analysts monitored the latest signals on U.S.-Mexico trade policy and bets on lower interest rates.

title: Deutsche Bank Credit Rating Downgraded by Fitch
summary: Long-term credit rating lowered to BBB from BBB+. Fitch Ratings on Friday downgraded Deutsche Bank AG's long-term debt rating, citing the German lender's low profitability and doubts about its business model.

title: You Have the Right to Bare Arms, but Why Ink Them?
summary: I shaved my youthful beard and threw away my ugly tie. What would I have done with a tattoo?. Warmer weather comes, and women put on summer dresses. Arms and shoulders may be bared. People will wear shorts, bathing suits. And we will become aware, again, of the tattoos-of the immense acreage of human flesh committed to artists' ink.

title: Must Freedom Destroy Itself?
summary: A Notre Dame political scientist attributes America's current discontent to the liberalism of the Founders. He sells their virtue short.. The election of Donald Trump, an outsider who routinely and joyfully violates America's political conventions, has spurred a lively debate about when and how U.S. politics went off the rails. Patrick J. Deneen's answer: in 1776, with the founding itself.

title: A Dearth of Data Helped Hong Kong Succeed
summary: Without statistics, you can't prepare a five-year plan-and that's good news for prosperity.. More data makes for better economic policy, right? Lessons from 20th-century India and Hong Kong suggest the opposite is true.

title: Medicaid Expansion has Louisianans Dropping Their Private Plans
summary: Thousands, including some earning six-figures, have opted for 'free' government health insurance.. If any state can serve as the poster child for the problems associated with ObamaCare's Medicaid expansion, it's Louisiana, which joined the expansion in 2016, after Democrat John Bel Edwards became governor. An audit released last year exposed ineligible Medicaid beneficiaries, including at least 1,672 people who made more than $100,000. But Louisiana's Medicaid expansion has revealed another waste of taxpayer funds, both in the Pelican State and nationwide: the money spent providing coverage to people who already had health insurance.

title: Cubans Pay for Trump's Travel Ban
summary: Sanctions and embargoes only make it easier for the Communists to blame America for their failures.. I run a small libertarian film festival, where I've screened documentaries about Cuban dissidents. These films made me want to visit Cuba to meet the people whose resilience I had come to admire. My husband and I were organizing an 80-person cruise this November and had arranged to host Armando Valladares and Rosa María Payá at a pre-cruise reception in Miami.

title: 'In Miniature' Review: Let's Get Small
summary: Minuscule scenes enthrall us because they require so much precision to produce-and give us a sense of control of what's not really in our grasp.. At a flea circus, there were no good seats. That didn't stop people from paying to crane their necks to witness the performers drive tiny carriages, jump through tiny hoops and walk a tiny tightrope. Most of the action was illusory: Attached to props, the fleas' "performances" were struggles to free themselves of their harnesses. The flea circus may have gotten its start in 1578, when a London jeweler named Mark Scaliot marketed his delicately lightweight metalworking by hitching a lock and chain to a flea. The tabletop spectacles became a phenomenon in the 1850s, however, and persisted into the 1960s before losing audiences to TV and movies.

title: Women In: The Conversation
'Time of My Life' Review: A Lad Gone Trad
summary: Clive Wilson, a British trumpeter and "jazz pilgrim," crossed the Atlantic after being seduced by the music of New Orleans.. In the common room of a boarding school just south of London, Clive Wilson, then 13 years old, heard "a tapestry of sound and rhythm" that summoned unfamiliar feelings. "I am not making any sense of what I am hearing," Mr. Wilson, now 76, recalls in this affecting memoir. "But in that moment, which remains with me today, making sense of my attraction is not important. Something stirs." "Tishomingo Blues," as recorded by trumpeter Bunk Johnson and his New Orleans Jazz Band, stirred Mr. Wilson enough to pick up the trumpet he's yet to put down, and to cross the Atlantic for good, for a life he couldn't have anticipated.

title: Judge Orders Mueller Witness to Jail in Child-Pornography Case
summary: George Nader acted as a conduit between senior Trump allies in the early days of the Trump administration.. ALEXANDRIA, Va.-A witness in special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation was ordered to jail Friday after prosecutors detailed what they described as a decadeslong interest in child pornography.

title: FedEx to End U.S. Express Business With Amazon
summary: Delivery giant, in severing U.S. air contract, says it wants to focus on other retailers. FedEx Corp. is ending its air-shipping contract with Amazon.com Inc. in the U.S., evidence of escalating tensions between the longtime partners as the e-commerce giant builds its own delivery network.

title: Insys Bankruptcy Could Undercut Government's $225 Million Opioid Deal
summary: Federal authorities would be unsecured creditors in a potential Insys bankruptcy, on par with lawyers and other creditors. Insys Therapeutics Inc. has agreed to pay $225 million to settle federal charges over its opioid sales, but that money could be tough to collect if the drugmaker files for bankruptcy, which it has said is a possibility.

title: Man Is Arrested Over Alleged Times Square Terror Plot
summary: Surveillance of suspect began last summer. A Queens man was charged Friday with buying illegal guns as part of an alleged plot to carry out a terrorist attack in New York City's Times Square.

title: Elliott Management to Buy Barnes & Noble
summary: Transaction represents 9.1% premium to bookseller's Thursday closing price; shares jump.. Barnes & Noble Inc. agreed to be bought by hedge fund Elliott Management Corp. for about $475 million in cash, the companies said Friday, setting up a new era for the troubled bookstore chain.

title: Trump's Tequila Tax and the Swamp
summary: If he keeps adding tariffs he'll give Washington the "revenue neutrality" it wanted in 2017.. Among President Donald Trump's most important negotiating counterparties, the government of Mexico is by far the most reasonable. Mr. Trump should take yes for an answer from our southern neighbors and cancel his plans to add new tariffs on Mexican products.

title: U.S. Added 75,000 Jobs in May as Hiring Slowed
summary: Jobless rate held steady at 3.6%, a half-century low. Employers tapped the brakes on hiring in May, signaling companies are taking a more cautious approach at a time of cooling global growth and trade tensions and underscoring a spring slowdown in the decadelong U.S. economic expansion.

title: Trump Sees 'Good Chance' of Migration Deal With Mexico
summary: President warns that tariffs will go into effect Monday if no agreement is reached. President Trump said Friday that "there is a good chance" that the U.S. would be able to strike a deal with Mexico on border security and migration, but again warned that tariffs would go into effect next week if no deal is reached.

title: Dollar Weakens in Wake of Jobs Report
summary: Tepid hiring data bolsters case for Fed to cut interest rates. The dollar fell against a broad range of currencies Friday, after a weak U.S. employment number bolstered the case for the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy sooner.

title: President Spoke With Fed Chairman Amid Public Campaign for Lower Rates
summary: Mr. Trump's phone call followed two proposed nominations of central-bank critics. WASHINGTON-President Trump spoke with Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell by phone in April during a period in which the White House escalated pressure on the central bank to keep interest rates low.

title: U.S. Sanctions Iranian Petrochemical Company
summary: Latest sanctions aim to increase pressure on Tehran. WASHINGTON-The U.S. sanctioned one of Iran's biggest petrochemical companies on Friday, hitting a top revenue earner as the Trump administration attempts to strong-arm Tehran into a new nuclear and security pact.

title: Bond Yields Extend Drop Toward 2%
summary: Muted inflation, slowing job growth put multiple Fed rate cuts on investors' minds.. The yield on benchmark U.S. government bonds hit new 2019 lows near 2% on Friday, a sign investors believe a slowing economy will spur the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates.

title: IRS Wins Again in Closely Watched Intel Tax Case
summary: Outcome could affect many U.S. tech companies. A federal appeals court upheld tax regulations on certain cross-border cost-sharing agreements within corporations, delivering a victory for the Internal Revenue Service over Intel Corp. in a case closely watched by tech companies.

title: Anadarko CEO to Get $98 Million Payout in Occidental Deal
summary: Al Walker is among the top Anadarko executives who will receive $300 million. Anadarko Petroleum Corp. Chief Executive Al Walker is set to receive a $98 million payout on completion of the company's $38 billion sale to Occidental Petroleum Corp.

title: Bold Plan for Detroit: Make Big Three Into Big Two
summary: A two-way combination between Fiat Chrysler, General Motors or Ford would offer domination of the lucrative pickups-and-SUV business. When Fiat Chrysler's pursuit of Renault fell apart this week, it drove home how fortune has rarely favored the bold in Detroit.

title: Gold Extends Rally After Jobs Report
summary: Gold prices are near their February 10-month peaks. Gold prices climbed for the eighth consecutive session Friday, nearing their February 10-month peaks after May hiring data missed expectations and stoked further fears of a U.S. economic slowdown.

title: Freight Operators Slowed Hiring in May on Weaker Shipping Demand
summary: Parcel carriers and warehouse companies continued adding jobs in a sign of the growing impact of e-commerce on logistics operations.. Logistics operators slowed their hiring in May amid signs of moderating freight demand across the broader American economy.

title: Growing Scholars Instead of Administrators
summary: It's tragic that faculties, who represent both the means of production and its very raison d'être, should have surrendered so meekly the major share of the pie to administrators.. Thanks to Philip Hamburger for explaining why college tuition has outpaced the consumer-price index by multiples over the past 50 years and far-outpaced the earnings value of degrees ("Stop Feeding College Bureaucratic Bloat," op-ed, June 3). It's tragic that faculties, who represent both the means of production and its very raison d'être, should have surrendered so meekly the major share of the pie; shocking also that it's taken so long to figure this out.

title: Shed No Tears for Violent, Unchanged Hamas
summary: Are we supposed to feel sorry for Hamas because it focuses on attacking Israel rather than investing in the people by building housing and schools and hospitals?. Regarding "Rejuvenated Hamas Tests Israel in High-Stakes Brinkmanship" (World News, June 4), Hamas is said to be under "tremendous financial hardship," yet they have found the resources to build up their supply of rockets and are still building elaborate tunnels into Israel. Are we supposed to feel sorry for Hamas because it focuses on attacking Israel rather than investing in the people by building housing and schools and hospitals?

title: Stacey Abrams Should Relocate to New York
summary: Stacey. Abrams ought to consider a carpetbagging move to New York where she can mount a primary challenge to our own unlikable Gov. Andrew Cuomo.. Karl Rove's excellent take on Stacey Abrams' bitter rout has given me a brainstorm. She's the candidate who would be Georgia's governor, except that she lost the 2018 election by 54,723 votes because of considerable, but fictitious, voter suppression of blacks ("Stacey Abrams Won't Go Away," op-ed, May 30).

title: Martha Dodd's Embassy Eyes Were Bright Red
summary: In fact, Ms. Dodd (like her husband) was indeed a Soviet agent and had been since her recruitment in 1930s Berlin.. In the review of Martha Dodd's 1939 memoir "Through Embassy Eyes" (Books, Five Best, June 1), Marie Brenner notes that Ms. Dodd and her husband fled first to Mexico City and later Prague as they were "under suspicion during the McCarthy years of being Soviet spies." In fact, Ms. Dodd (like her husband) was indeed a Soviet agent and had been since her recruitment in 1930s Berlin where she was particularly active, as her father was U.S. ambassador there. According to "The Haunted Wood: Soviet Espionage in America-the Stalin Era" (1998) by Allen Weinstein and Alexander Vassiliev, the Soviet Venona files which they studied amply confirm Ms. Dodd's long record as a Soviet spy. Clearly, one should read the late Ms. Dodd's book with these unsettling facts in mind.

title: Democrats Plan Contempt Votes for Barr, Ross Over Census Question
summary: Opponents say citizenship question would cause fewer people to respond to the census. WASHINGTON-The House Oversight and Reform Committee failed to reach an agreement with Attorney General William Barr and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross and will move forward with a contempt vote next week for ignoring its subpoena seeking information about efforts to add a citizenship question to the 2020 census.

title: D-Day Nostalgia and the West's New Realities
summary: NATO was created to deal with very different threats from those we now face.. A few years into the Afghan war, I had the chance to visit the country at the invitation of the NATO mission there. After a couple of days in Kabul, a small group of us-journalists, think tankers, ex-administration types-were flown out to Herat in the west of the country, close to the Iranian border. There we spent a day observing the work of Italian soldiers in keeping the peace and helping rebuild.

title: Ex-Minneapolis Officer Sentenced to 12 ½ Years in Shooting of 911 Caller
summary: Victim approached his squad car minutes after calling 911 to report a possible rape. MINNEAPOLIS-A Minneapolis police officer convicted of murder was sentenced to 12½ years in prison on Friday in the fatal shooting of an unarmed woman who approached his squad car minutes after calling 911 to report a possible rape.

title: IBM Cuts About 2,000 Jobs
summary: Company continues to shift its business toward 'high-value segments'. International Business Machines Corp. is cutting about 2,000 jobs in a round of layoffs this week, according to a person familiar with the matter, as the technology giant works to reshape its business.

title: Elliott Buyout Ambitions Dust Off Barnes & Noble
summary: Hedge fund-turned-private equity shop has taken on tough task buying bookseller as early foray into takeovers. Elliott Management can't be accused of taking the easy way out.

title: Colorado School District Proposes Tearing Down Columbine High School
summary: Superintendent cites 'morbid fascination' with campus following 1999 mass shooting. Colorado school officials are considering demolishing Columbine High School and rebuilding a new campus, in a drastic step that comes 20 years after a deadly shooting on school grounds left 13 people dead.

title: Softer Labor Market Could Strengthen Case for Rate Cut
summary: Fed officials are watching whether weakness in the factory sector is seeping into the economy's much bigger service sector. The May employment report adds to signs the U.S. economy was cooling even before the recent escalation in trade tensions-which could make it easier for Federal Reserve officials to justify an interest rate cut at their meeting later this month or in July.

title: 'There's a Fantasy League for That?' Sumo Wrestling and Fishing Drafts Become Reality
summary: Virtual baseball, football are so passé. But fans creating fantasy lineups for birding and curling face furrowed brows; 'You mean, that thing with the brooms?'. Scott Chu prepared for his fantasy sports league's big event with a bold strategy: Combine a champ with an underdog.

title: Monster Looks Beyond Energy Drinks Into Alcohol
summary: Beverage company trying to diversify amid rising competition, including from investor Coca-Cola. Monster Beverage Corp. , the U.S. leader in energy drinks, is considering an expansion into booze.

title: The Art of Great Migrations
summary: In the U.S. and around the world, the movement of peoples has been documented in works of art.. The thorny issue of migration is about to surface in Washington, D.C., again-but this time, it will be in the galleries of the Phillips Collection. "The Warmth of Other Suns: Stories of Global Displacement," a new exhibition on view from June 22 to Sept. 22, includes artworks about great migrations in the American past-from the Europeans who passed through Ellis Island to the Oklahomans who went west during the 1930s. But the heart of the show is a collection of works by roughly 75 artists around the world, most of them immigrants-including the abstract expressionist Mark Rothko, who was born in what is today Latvia before moving to the U.S., and El Anatsui, who emigrated from Ghana to Nigeria and is known for shimmering sculptures using bottle tops and other found objects.

title: Fresh Tariffs Raise New Barriers for Steelmakers
summary: Canada and Mexico are top destinations for U.S. steel. Executives at U.S. steelmakers said fresh tariffs on goods from Mexico threaten to undermine benefits from a North American trade pact that they were counting on to boost their business.

title: Mortgage Lender Herbert Sandler Fought to Restore Reputation After Housing Bust
summary: Co-founder of Golden West Financial, who funded investigative journalism, was pilloried in the press. During a 43-year career in the home-mortgage business, Herbert Sandler cultivated a reputation for careful lending at Golden West Financial Corp., the company he built with his wife, Marion. They insisted on substantial down payments, promoted minority homeownership and kept loans on their own books rather than selling them to Wall Street.

title: With an Eye on China, Russia's Putin Blasts U.S. Dominance
summary: Russian and Chinese presidents' rhetoric underscores strengthening ties: Moscow is 'sincere and like-minded' says China's Xi Jinping. ST. PETERSBURG, RUSSIA-Russian President Vladimir Putin accused the Trump administration of using tariffs and sanctions to maintain dominance of the global economy, while highlighting the Kremlin's increasingly warm ties with China, as the two countries' relationship with Washington deteriorates.

title: Zoom Is Running Too Hot
summary: Video-communications upstart justifies IPO enthusiasm with first report, but the stock's valuation has still gotten ahead of itself. Can you have too much of a good thing? Investors in Zoom Video Communications seem determined to find out.

title: Sharing Services Need to Have More Imagination
summary: If there are short-term rentals for scooters, why not for ties, Jet Skis and 401ks?. When people come up with fantastic ideas like bike-sharing, scooter-sharing and, most recently, car-sharing, they cavalierly ignore the tens of millions of Americans who already have our own bikes and cars. And a lot of us wouldn't be seen dead on a scooter, the clownish version of a Segway.

title: Eileen Fisher on How She Learned to Invest
summary: Fashion designer explains cutting through investment jargon in WSJ's 'Secrets of Wealthy Women' podcast. In 2006, Eileen Fisher decided that rather than taking her women's clothing brand public or getting acquired, she would transfer ownership to her employees. To do so, Ms. Fisher would offer an Employee Stock Ownership Plan, or ESOP.

title: Third-Person Singular
summary: Julius Caesar's 'Commentaries on the Gallic War' discuss military history, ethnography and the vagaries of human nature with masterful clarity and incisiveness..

title: Lessons From a Rare Breed: Wall Street Bears
summary: While 'sell' calls are a fraction of analysts' recommendations, these researchers issued timely warnings on Valeant, home builders and Enron. The list of analysts who have made their name on bearish stock calls isn't long. The Wall Street Journal tracked down some to talk about their experiences.

title: A Suicide Attempt, an Order to Keep Silent: A U.S. Agency Mishandled Sex-Abuse Claims
The Long Road to the Student Debt Crisis
summary: A series of well-intentioned government decisions since the 1960s has left us with today's out-of-control higher education market.. The U.S. student loan system is broken.

title: Toy Mogul Isaac Larian Plays for Keeps
summary: The man behind Bratz dolls has a new hit on his hands, a talent for capturing children's attention and a reputation for hard-driving tactics. The toy mogul Isaac Larian strode to the dais during his industry's premier event, the Toy Association's Toy of the Year Awards ceremony in February, to claim the top prize-and to take a swipe at a nemesis. "Thank you everybody, even the people at Mattel , " Mr. Larian said. As the ballroom in New York City filled with nervous laughter, he added, "I love most of you. I just don't like Bob 'Abnormal'"-a jab at Mattel Inc.'s longtime general counsel, Robert Normile.

title: What You Need to Know About 'ISA' College Deals
summary: How to figure out whether income-share agreements are a good choice for you. Income-share agreements are starting to gain traction as a college-funding option. But because they are so new, many students and families don't know much about them.

title: Teneo Agrees to Sell Majority Stake to Private-Equity Firm
summary: Deal values fast-growing advisory firm at more than $700 Million. Teneo Holdings LLC-the communications and advisory firm known for counseling the CEOs of some of the world's largest companies-has agreed to sell a slight majority stake to private-equity investor CVC Capital Partners, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: What's a Kilogram? The Hunk of Metal That Defined It for 130 Years Has Been Retired
summary: The closely guarded cylinder of platinum-iridium, kept under strict control in France, has outlived its usefulness.

title: A Worrying Jobs Number With Trade Hit Looming
summary: May's jobs data is especially worrying because it comes before any real hit from the latest trade tensions. It is just one employment report, but it sure wasn't a good one. That puts the Federal Reserve in an uncomfortable bind.

title: Brazil Ruling Eases Sales of State-Owned Subsidiaries
summary: Supreme Court decision aids cash-strapped government, frees Petrobras to continue divestments. SÃO PAULO-Brazil's Supreme Court voted to allow the government to sell subsidiaries of state companies without congressional approval, making it easier for President Jair Bolsonaro's administration to raise money, cut debt and attract private investment as the economy struggles.

title: A Venture Capitalist's Swanky Boston Penthouse Asks $28 Million
summary: Owner Todd Dagres is selling a 7,000-square-foot condo, which comes with a screening room-cum-dance studio and art gallery spaces. Todd Dagres, a venture capitalist whose firm profited from an early investment in Twitter , is listing his Boston penthouse for $28 million. If the home sells for close to its asking price, it would become one of the priciest condos ever sold in the Massachusetts city.

title: Beyond Meat Enriches Shareholders with Wisdom
summary: Resume Subscription. Beyond Meat isn't just the hottest stock in the U.S.; its conference calls may become a destination for inspirational thinking.

summary: Today's Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Leaders mark 75th anniversary of D-Day, Andy Ruiz stuns champion Anthony Joshua, Virginia Beach mourns, and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'Underland' Review: What Lives Beneath
summary: A word-loving adventurer plumbs the worlds below the Earth's surface-from Yorkshire caves to a Finnish nuclear-waste dump-and the myth and metaphor that surround them.. The underworld is both close by and impossibly distant. In most places, the base of the Earth's crust is only about 20 miles beneath our feet, but it is less accessible than the surface of the moon. The deepest boreholes ever drilled-in a ludicrous geologic competition between NATO countries and the Soviet bloc during the Cold War-reached depths of just 7 miles. Geoscientists can peer, virtually, further into the subsurface using seismic waves, spatial variations in the pull of gravity, and rocks churned up by erosion and tectonics, but eyewitness observation of subterranean realms is limited to places where the Earth is perforated with human-size openings: caves, catacombs, sewers, mines-most less than 1,000 feet deep. These are the murky haunts explored in Robert Macfarlane's "Underland: A Deep Time Journey."

title: 'The White Devil's Daughters' Review: A Chinatown Safe House
summary: San Francisco's Mission Home was a refuge for many young women escaping human trafﬁckers.. In San Francisco's Chinatown at the turn of the 20th century, women were valuable commodities. Waves of immigration from China that had begun five decades earlier brought mostly men to the shores of the United States, where they found work as laborers, laundrymen and household servants. By 1870, the Chinese population of San Francisco numbered 10 men for every woman. That imbalance made for a thriving sex trade: Of the 2,000 or so Chinese women whom census workers counted in the city that year, some 71% worked as either prostitutes or brothel operators.

title: 'Blimp': A World War I Term That's Taken on a Weighted Meaning
summary: Controversy has long surrounded the origins of the aircraft's name, which eventually came to be used to describe a corpulent person. President Trump's visit to London this week saw the return of the 20-foot "Trump Baby" blimp in Parliament Square Garden, an orange, diaper-wearing depiction of the president that was first set aloft by protesters when he visited the U.K. last year. This time, the protest group also inflated a smaller replica during their demonstration, but the mini-blimp was punctured by a Trump supporter.

title: Investors, Buy the Dips: The Economic Cycle Isn't What It Used to Be
summary: Though the economic expansion may linger on, a debt-fueled crisis could still explode down the road. But it may be further away that you think.. It may be time for investors to stop worrying and learn to love the boom. The inevitable bust could be further off than is commonly believed, but it could also be more painful.

title: States Prepare to Launch Investigations Into Tech Giants
summary: Group of AGs has been discussing how to address antitrust-related concerns with Google, Facebook, Apple and Amazon. WASHINGTON-State attorneys general are preparing for their own investigations into big tech platforms including Google and Facebook , based on concerns that largely mirror those driving probes by the Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and Congress.

title: 'The Widow Washington' Review: Mary, Mother of George
summary: It was Mary Ball Washington who instilled in the ﬁrst president a moral philosophy of industry, thrift and stoicism.. Like many mothers of famous men, Mary Ball Washington has been the object of both beatifying praise and disdainful condemnation. Ron Chernow's 2010 biography of her eldest son, George, followed a long tradition in calling her "shrewish," "hypercritical" and "illiterate." Today people might be inclined to denounce her as a woman of privilege who, unlike her son, never questioned holding human beings in bondage or separating them from their families.

title: 'The Universe Speaks in Numbers' Review: The Inner Observatory
summary: Since Pythagoras, thinkers have dreamed of understanding the universe entirely through mathematics.. One day in the fifth century B.C., if legend be credited, the philosopher Hippasus of Metapontum boarded a ship and set sail across the Mediterranean. Hippasus was a member of the Pythagorean brotherhood, a sect that held that the world is structured by whole numbers and their ratios. Mathematical reasoning, they believed, would yield all truths of the world.

title: 'Cosmological Koans' Review: Matter and Mystics
summary: Eastern philosophies can have an uncanny congruence with cutting-edge physics.. 'Physicists do not need mysticism, and mystics do not need physics, but humanity needs both." So wrote Fritjof Capra, whose book "The Tao of Physics" became a best seller in 1975 and has now been issued in 43 editions and published in 23 languages. Mr. Capra offered the first exposition of the congruence between Eastern mysticism and modern subatomic physics, but several other works followed in the same vein, including Gary Zukav's "The Dancing Wu Li Masters," which won the 1980 National Book Award in the science category.

title: Fiction: Inappropriate Attachments
summary: Three tales of mad desire, in which smart people are led into folly by their bodies' unbearable urges.. The appearance of Adam Foulds's latest book, "Dream Sequence" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 211 pages, $25), is, to begin with, an occasion to recommend his previous novels, "The Quickening Maze," about the Romantic poet John Clare's time in a mental asylum, and "In the Wolf's Mouth," set during the Allied invasion of Sicily in World War II. The raw, concentrated intensity of the writing in these books, whether the landscape is a mind in meltdown or the havoc of the battlefield, has rarely been equalled in contemporary fiction. The sentences seem scoured, even mortified, by Mr. Foulds's obsessive noticing. Reading them is a physical experience. You feel in danger of sensory overload.

title: Book Review: Booth Tarkington's Novels & Stories
summary: His ﬁction shows a Midwest holding to traditional social codes while irreversible change sweeps over it.. Poor Booth Tarkington-ignored if not forgotten, despite a mellifluous name that any writer could envy. It's as if he's gotten lost, somewhere between his contemporary and fellow Hoosier Theodore Dreiser, and F. Scott Fitzgerald, born some 30 years later, who once confessed that Compton Mackenzie and Tarkington "together taught me all I know about the English language." It's a pity that Tarkington's best novels are better known for the films that were made of them: above all, Orson Welles's "The Magnificent Ambersons" (1942), and "Alice Adams" (1935), with Katharine Hepburn in the starring role. But the estimable Library of America may revive his reputation with a hefty placemark in the canon: a volume, edited by the novelist Thomas Mallon, containing those two novels along with the six stories from the collection "In the Arena: Stories of Political Life."

title: Five Best: Yuri Slezkine on Keeping the Faith
summary: The author, most recently, of "The House of Government: A Saga of the Russian Revolution.". By Nikolai Ostrovsky (1934)

title: Children's Books: Why They Love to Hop on Pop
summary: Picture books that celebrate the tender, playful, capable modern father.. What are the traits that make fathers distinctive? Are the best dads giggly and snuggly, natural nurses, adept in the kitchen and laundry room, and good at fixing girls' hair? If that's your view, then for Father's Day you may wish to have a look at the tranche of new picture books that make a point of celebrating, in fathers, skills and qualities once associated more with mothers. There's nothing wrong with men doing domestic tasks, of course. But as realms of masculine distinction, the kitchen and laundry room are not exactly the beaches of Normandy. For readers who prefer to see fathers depicted as capable and authoritative, as well as tender and playful, here are a few books that combine captivating illustration with a respect for manliness.

title: Mysteries: A Most Victorian Conspiracy
summary: New crime fiction set in London, in Dickens's time and our own.. London in 1860 is the principal setting of Tim Mason's "The Darwin Affair" (Algonquin, 373 pages, $27.95), which evokes the pleasures of such period authors as Wilkie Collins, Arthur Conan Doyle and Charles Dickens. The last of these, in fact, is among a host of historical figures-including Queen Victoria, Karl Marx and the titular Charles Darwin-whose cameo appearances further enliven this memorable page-turner.

title: Judith Kerr Told Her Daughter a Tale and Found a Career
summary: Refugee from the Nazis wrote 'The Tiger Who Came to Tea' and other children's books. When Judith Kerr fled Nazi Germany in 1933, she was 9 years old and felt she was going on a grand adventure. There was a train ride to Zurich, a spell in a Parisian school long enough for her to master French and finally her arrival in London, where she lived with her parents and brother in a series of cheap hotels.

title: Andrew Craig Helped Lead Wave of Consolidation Among U.S. Banks
summary: CEO built Boatmen's into a big regional player, then extracted a rich price from NationsBank. Emerging from Army service in 1957, Andrew Craig had job offers from International Business Machines Corp. and a drug company. He saw more opportunity in banking.

title: Trump to Meet Qatar's Emir to Discuss Ties
summary: Sheikh Tamim Bin Hamad al-Thani to visit the White House in July. WASHINGTON-President Trump will meet Qatari Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani at the White House on July 9, months after administration officials traveled to the Middle East to drum up support for their Israeli-Palestinian peace plan.

title: Amanda Anisimova Falls at French Open Semifinal
summary: Anisimova loses in three sets against Ashleigh Barty, who will face Markéta Vondroušová in the final. PARIS-Amanda Anisimova, just 17 years old, came close to an improbable French Open comeback before losing in three sets against Ashleigh Barty, 6-7(4), 6-3, 6-3.

title: Mexican Inflation Rate Eased in May
summary: Report comes as threat of U.S. tariffs poses new risks. MEXICO CITY-Mexican consumer prices fell more than expected in May, pushing the annual inflation rate down as lower energy costs offset higher food prices, and prices of vacation-related services were lower after the Easter holiday season.

title: Rafa & Roger in Paris: A Rivalry Becomes a Rout
summary: Rafael Nadal powers his way to another French Open final with a persuasive victory over Roger Federer. PARIS-Roger Federer came to Paris to play the French Open for the first time in four years, and he played well, reaching the semifinals of a tournament he's only won once, a decade ago. But on Friday afternoon, Le Fed ran into a familiar nemesis-a man who doesn't really lose at this tournament, and has never lost to Federer here, not once:

title: Anticipation of a Rate Cut Rises With Jobs Report
summary: Investors who trade futures have placed a 79% chance of a rate cut at Fed's July meeting. May's underwhelming jobs report has raised the stakes of an interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve, as major indexes rallied again Friday.

title: Frackers Scrounge for Cash as Wall Street Closes Doors
summary: With traditional financing options dwindling, shale companies explore costlier alternatives. Shale drillers are scrambling to raise cash as financing from Wall Street dries up.

title: The Perennial Joys of a Professional Rose Grower
summary: Resume Subscription. On rainy days, Lauren Kope pores over stacks of century-old garden plans, pondering the past. Ms. Kope, 30 years old, works as rosarian for Wyck Historic House and Garden in Philadelphia, where she catalogs and tends to the nation's oldest continuously preserved rose garden, which dates to 1824.

title: Canada Jobless Rate Fell in May to Record Low
summary: Employment growth slowed after record-breaking April; unemployment rate falls on sharp decline in people looking for work. OTTAWA-Employment growth in Canada slowed in May after an extraordinary jobs gain in April, while the jobless rate fell to a record low as the number of people searching for work declined sharply.

title: Fashion Designer Cecilie Bahnsen on How to Switch Off in Sicily
summary: The Danish designer talks about road tripping through Italy, being an impulsive packer and bringing a disposable camera on holiday. In this series, we talk to our favorite designers, artists and entertainers about where they're traveling this summer, what they're packing, how they stay entertained in-flight and more.

title: ECB's Big Bazooka Is Losing Ammunition as Economy Teeters
summary: The ECB is constrained in how forcefully it can deploy traditional stimulus measures. The European Central Bank has pushed interest rates into negative territory and bought trillions of euros in bonds to sustain the eurozone's economy. Now, with the economic expansion flagging, a critical question is emerging: How much does it have left in the tank?

title: Trump Brings Rare Dose of Stability to a Continent in Flux
summary: Though he launched a few barbs at domestic targets, the U.S. president was diplomatic with his European counterparts. COLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France-At a time of political upheaval across the European Union, it was President Trump who was the relative picture of stability-both diplomatically and politically-as he skipped back and forth across the English Channel this week.

title: Mammoth Energy Stands By Its Work in Puerto Rico Following Investigation
summary: U.S. officials are looking into a subsidiary's dominance in restoring power to island after Hurricane Maria. Mammoth Energy Services Inc. said it is standing by the hurricane repair work a subsidiary did in Puerto Rico, after The Wall Street Journal reported U.S. authorities were examining the company's role in restoring power to the island.

title: New Huawei Phones Won't Come With Facebook, Instagram or WhatsApp
summary: Facebook is the latest company to restrict access to its products following the U.S. blacklisting of the Chinese tech giant. Facebook Inc. will no longer allow its apps to come pre-installed on mobile devices made by Huawei Technologies Co., dealing another blow to the Chinese tech giant following its blacklisting by U.S. authorities on national security grounds.

title: MLB Sends a Message to High Schoolers: Go to College
summary: This year's draft continues a trend away from high-schoolers and toward players with college experience. Major League Baseball held its amateur draft this week, and the results sent a resounding message to kids around the country: If you want to play in the Show, stay in school.

title: Brexit Party Falls Short in Its First Parliamentary Election Challenge
summary: The result offers an ominous warning to the ruling Conservative Party, which came in third. LONDON-The U.K.'s opposition Labour Party fended off the upstart, euroskeptic Brexit Party in a by-election touted as a litmus test for a protest movement that threatens to reshape British politics.

title: Boris Johnson Is Running for Britain's Top Job. Again.
summary: The Brexit cheerleader and favorite in the race to succeed Theresa May is trying to shed his gaffe-prone image. The hair is trimmed. The jokes have stopped. And Alexander Boris de Pfeffel Johnson is ready, again, to have a go at becoming Britain's prime minister.

title: Hackers Won't Let Up in Their Attack on U.S. Cities
summary: Baltimore is still recovering month after more than one group breached its network. BALTIMORE-Local governments across the country are facing a growing threat of cyberattacks and escalating ransom demands, as an attack in this city has crippled thousands of computers for a month.

title: Walmart Wants to Put Groceries Into Your Fridge
summary: Retail giant to offer in-home grocery delivery in three cities later this year. Walmart Inc. is opening a new front in home-delivery services: carting milk, eggs and other groceries and leaving them in the fridge.

title: Treasury Yields Fall to Fresh 2019 Lows After Weak Jobs Data
summary: Investors ratchet up bets for multiple Fed rate cuts this year. U.S. government bond yields fell to fresh 2019 lows Friday, after the Labor Department said the economy added fewer jobs in May than economists had expected.

title: Auto Makers Push Trump to Reach Fuel Compromise
summary: GM, Ford, Toyota and more than a dozen other car companies sign letter to president. A group of the world's largest auto makers is urging President Trump to work out a compromise with California officials on new fuel-economy regulations, warning that his plan to ease standards could provoke a standoff that would hamstring future planning.

title: YouTube's Efforts to Scrub Hate Speech Spawn Vicious Reaction Online
summary: The pace of threatening messages directed at the Alphabet unit has accelerated since Wednesday's move. YouTube's steps this week to block hate-based and conspiracy-mongering videos have sparked a backlash online, according to social-media intelligence firm Storyful.

title: Biden Reverses Stance on Hyde Amendment, Citing Roe v. Wade
summary: 'It was not under attack...as it is now. But circumstances have changed,' he said in Atlanta speech. WASHINGTON-Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden said Thursday night that he now opposes a ban on the use of federal funds for most abortions, reversing his longstanding position amid pressure from fellow Democrats and abortion-rights groups.

title: U.A.E. Stops Short of Directly Blaming Iran in Ship Attacks
summary: U.S. has directly accused Iran's elite military unit of carrying out the attacks last month near the Strait of Hormuz. The United Arab Emirates said Thursday that special forces from a hostile nation likely carried out coordinated attacks last month on four ships near the Strait of Hormuz, but stopped short of directly accusing Iran.

title: U.S. Plans More Than $2 Billion in Weapons Sales to Taiwan, Angering Beijing
summary: Potential arms sale risks inflaming tensions amid trade dispute. WASHINGTON-The U.S. is planning a new effort to help the Taiwanese government upgrade its military by allowing Taipei to buy billions of dollars' worth of weapons systems, possibly including more than 100 tanks-a move that has already drawn criticism from Beijing.

title: West Point Cadet Dies in Accident Near Summer Training Camp
summary: Nineteen other cadets and two soldiers were injured after a troop vehicle rolled over. A West Point cadet died Thursday after a troop vehicle rolled over on the way to a summer training exercise at the U.S. Military Academy, officials said.

title: Fitch Cuts Mexico's Pemex to Below Investment Grade
summary: Outlook for state oil company remains negative, reflecting potential for further decline in credit profile. MEXICO CITY-Fitch Ratings downgraded Mexico's highly indebted state oil company Petróleos Mexicanos, stripping it of its investment-grade rating.

title: U.S., Mexico Make Progress on Migration Issues, but Tariffs Still Loom
summary: White House official says Trump administration is encouraged by delegation's ideas on how to stem flow from the south, but plans to impose levies next week. The Trump administration has made significant progress in its border-security negotiations with Mexico, a senior White House official said, but the U.S. remained on track to impose tariffs on the country's imports next week.

title: Fed Lifts Requirements on JPMorgan Stemming From 'London Whale' Losses
summary: The Federal Reserve cited improvements in the New York bank's internal auditing and risk management controls. The Federal Reserve has lifted requirements imposed six years ago on JPMorgan Chase & Co. in the aftermath of trading losses that cost the New York bank around $6 billion.
